    • Scaling of standard deviation and mean body mass

Simulate populations

Source: vignettes/sim_populations.Rmd
sim_populations.Rmd

Simulate populations of individuals of a single species

The core functionality of birdsize is to simulate individual body mass measurements for birds given either their species ID or a mean (and possibly standard deviation) of body mass. simulate_population achieves this for a single species. simulate_community uses simulate_population to simulate body masses for multiple populations of birds of different species.

Using species identity

For most birds in the North American Breeding Bird Survey, you can use the species’ code (AOU) to simulate a population directly. For the hummingbird Selasphorus calliope:


a_hundred_hummingbirds <- simulate_population(species_abundance = 100, species_code = 244)

head(a_hundred_hummingbirds)
#>   species_code species_mean_mass species_sd_mass species_abundance
#> 1          244              2.65       0.1828933               100
#> 2          244              2.65       0.1828933               100
#> 3          244              2.65       0.1828933               100
#> 4          244              2.65       0.1828933               100
#> 5          244              2.65       0.1828933               100
#> 6          244              2.65       0.1828933               100
#>       simulation_method individual_mass
#> 1 species code provided        2.556333
#> 2 species code provided        3.104524
#> 3 species code provided        2.834325
#> 4 species code provided        2.703554
#> 5 species code provided        2.611783
#> 6 species code provided        2.989833

ggplot(a_hundred_hummingbirds, aes(individual_mass)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) +
  xlab("Mass (g)") +
  ylab("Count") +
  ggtitle("A population of hummingbirds")

To look up the AOU based on the species’ scientific name, explore the included sd_table dataset:

sd_table
#> # A tibble: 421 × 6
#>    species_id genus      species     mean_mass mean_sd contains_estimates
#>         <int> <chr>      <chr>           <dbl>   <dbl> <lgl>             
#>  1         27 Alopochen  aegyptiaca      1873    133.  TRUE              
#>  2         28 Cairina    moschata        2450    175.  TRUE              
#>  3         77 Ortalis    vetula           563     55   FALSE             
#>  4         85 Oreortyx   pictus           233     16.4 TRUE              
#>  5         90 Colinus    virginianus      172     12.1 TRUE              
#>  6         92 Callipepla squamata         184     13.0 TRUE              
#>  7         94 Callipepla californica      166.    14.3 TRUE              
#>  8         95 Callipepla gambelii         166     11.7 TRUE              
#>  9         96 Cyrtonyx   montezumae       186.    16.8 FALSE             
#> 10        100 Alectoris  chukar           504.    35.6 TRUE              
#> # … with 411 more rows

Using a known mean and standard deviation

Alternatively, you can simulate body masses for a population by supplying the body size parameters yourself. This may be useful if you would like to work with a species not included in the sd_table, test sensitivities to different parameter ranges, or generate values for simulation/null models (or, other applications!).

Note that, if both mean mass and a species code are provided, the species code will be used and the mean mass provided will be ignored!


a_hundred_hypotheticals <- simulate_population(species_abundance = 100, species_mean = 25, species_sd = 3)

head(a_hundred_hypotheticals)
#>   species_code species_mean_mass species_sd_mass species_abundance
#> 1           NA                25               3               100
#> 2           NA                25               3               100
#> 3           NA                25               3               100
#> 4           NA                25               3               100
#> 5           NA                25               3               100
#> 6           NA                25               3               100
#>      simulation_method individual_mass
#> 1 mean and sd provided        19.86281
#> 2 mean and sd provided        22.60234
#> 3 mean and sd provided        20.76744
#> 4 mean and sd provided        26.59827
#> 5 mean and sd provided        23.80690
#> 6 mean and sd provided        24.14694

ggplot(a_hundred_hypotheticals, aes(individual_mass)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) +
  xlab("Mass (g)") +
  ylab("Count") +
  ggtitle("A population of hypothetical birds", subtitle ="Mean mass = 25 g\nStandard deviation = 3")

Using a known mean, but no standard deviation

If the mean mass is not known or not provided, simulate_population will estimate the standard deviation based on scaling between the mean and standard deviation of body mass:



another_hundred_hypotheticals <- simulate_population(species_abundance = 100, species_mean = 25)

head(another_hundred_hypotheticals)
#>   species_code species_mean_mass species_sd_mass species_abundance
#> 1           NA                25        1.743992               100
#> 2           NA                25        1.743992               100
#> 3           NA                25        1.743992               100
#> 4           NA                25        1.743992               100
#> 5           NA                25        1.743992               100
#> 6           NA                25        1.743992               100
#>                 simulation_method individual_mass
#> 1 sd estimated from mean provided        26.24259
#> 2 sd estimated from mean provided        21.45239
#> 3 sd estimated from mean provided        20.80068
#> 4 sd estimated from mean provided        23.76115
#> 5 sd estimated from mean provided        22.17548
#> 6 sd estimated from mean provided        22.58924

ggplot(another_hundred_hypotheticals, aes(individual_mass)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) +
  xlab("Mass (g)") +
  ylab("Count") +
  ggtitle("A population of hypothetical birds", subtitle ="Mean mass = 25 g\nStandard deviation = 1.74")
